text:
### Fixes / new features
- https://github.com/PyCQA/astroid/issues/358
- old version of setuptools
  
  ``` bash
  $ python -c "from setuptools import __version__ as setuptools_version;from sys import version_info as py_version;print 'py_version', py_version;print 'setuptools_version', setuptools_version"
  py_version sys.version_info(major=2, minor=7, micro=10, releaselevel='final', serial=0)
  setuptools_version 1.1.6
  
  $ pip install --upgrade git+https://github.com/moylop260/astroid.git@6760ea
  Successfully installed astroid-1.5.0
  ```
- new version of setuptools
  
  ``` bash
  $ python -c "from setuptools import __version__ as setuptools_version;from sys import version_info as py_version;print 'py_version', py_version;print 'setuptools_version', setuptools_version"
  py_version sys.version_info(major=2, minor=7, micro=10, releaselevel='final', serial=0)
  setuptools_version 26.0.0
  py_version sys.version_info(major=2, minor=7, micro=10, releaselevel='final', serial=0)
  setuptools_version 26.0.0
  
  $ pip install --upgrade git+https://github.com/moylop260/astroid.git@6760ea
  Successfully installed astroid-1.5.0
  ```
title: [REF] package: Compatibility with old version of setuptools

Looks good. Check those two small comments I've left and we are good to go. Thank you.

You can't just compare strings:

```
>>> '3.0.0' < '21.0.0'
False
```

See what [pytest does](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/master/setup.py#L44) here.

setuptools 3.3 is sufficient for the environment marker "`python_version`", so you can use
`setuptools_version < (3, 3)`
title: (None, '', u'astroid/__pkginfo__.py')

text:
@jayvdb Thanks for clarify

I added (new commit) the following comment:

> The first known release to support environment marker with range operators
>     it is 17.1, see: https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/history.html#id113

It is important the **range operators** because we are using a range with `python_version<"3.4"`

text:
We need validate that works with current travis setuptools version and with newest setuptools version.
Then, we need execute the tests without a `pip -U` (old version) and run the tests again after a `pip -U` (new version)

``` bash
# test with old setuptools version:
python -m tox -e coverage-erase,$TOXENV

# Update newest setuptools version:
$PYTHON_EXE -m pip install -U setuptools

# test with newest setuptools version:
python -m tox -e coverage-erase,$TOXENV
```
title: (4, '', u'.travis.yml')

I removed it and If we find a new issue we could add the explicit except.
